title-group.article-title: Using awareness to Z-control a SEIR model with overexposure: Insights on Covid-19 pandemic

contrib-group.aff: aDipartimento di Ingegneria Elettrica e dell’Informazione, Università di Cassino e del Lazio Meridionale, via Di Biasio, Cassino I-03043, Italy
bIstituto per le Applicazioni del Calcolo M. Picone,CNR, Via Amendola 122, Bari I-70126, Italy

license.license-p: Since January 2020 Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information in English and Mandarin on the novel coronavirus COVID-19. The COVID-19 resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier hereby grants permission to make all its COVID-19-related research that is available on the COVID-19 resource centre - including this research content - immediately available in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database with rights for unrestricted research re-use and analyses in any form or by any means with acknowledgement of the original source. These permissions are granted for free by Elsevier for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active.

abstract.p: In this paper, we use the Z-control approach to get further insight on the role of awareness in the management of epidemics that, just like Covid-19, display a high rate of overexposure because of the large number of asymptomatic people. We focus on a SEIR model including a overexposure mechanism and consider awareness as a time-dependent variable whose dynamics is not assigned a priori. Exploiting the potential of awareness to produce social distancing and self-isolation among susceptibles, we use it as an indirect control on the class of infective individuals and apply the Z-control approach to detect what trend must awareness display over time in order to eradicate the disease. To this aim, we generalize the Z-control procedure to appropriately treat an uncontrolled model with more than two governing equations. Analytical and numerical investigations on the resulting Z-controlled system show its capability in controlling some representative dynamics within both the backward and the forward scenarios. The awareness variable is qualitatively compared to Google Trends data on Covid-19 that are discussed in the perspective of the Z-control approach, inferring qualitative indications in view of the disease control. The cases of Italy and New Zealand in the first phase of the pandemic are analyzed in detail. The theoretical framework of the Z-control approach can hence offer the chance to reflect on the use of Google Trends as a possible indicator of good management of the epidemic.

sec.title: Introduction and motivations
sec.p: Since the outbreak of the Covid19 epidemic in China, different mathematical models have been formulated to shed light on the severity of this infection as well as to gain predictions on the course of its spread. In many cases, detailed compartmental models with many classes have been introduced to estimate the risk of transmission of the novel coronavirus [1], [2] and to evaluate the effectiveness, even in the long period, of control measures against epidemic [3], [4]. In other cases, simpler qualitative models have been proposed to clarify the different mechanisms underlying its diffusion and to elucidate their reciprocal interplay.

One of the key point that emerged is that undocumented cases - including the asymptomatic ones - play an important role on the spread of the novel Coronavirus epidemic [5], [6], [7], [8] suggesting the importance to monitor, as best as possible, the real spread of the virus in the population. This marked role played by asymptomatic individuals, along with the peculiar disease transmission mechanism, prompted to consider social-distancing and persistent self-isolation as very effective control measures to fight epidemic. On this line, the combined action of the restrictive government measures (lockdown) and of media-driven awareness programs have played a very crucial role in softening the severity of the epidemic. Most countries and the World Health Organization (WHO) have used the great potential of Internet to promote awareness and educational programs on Covid19 and surveying the Relative Internet Search Volumes (RSV) was deemed as a means to give information on the extent of public attention, with Google Trends as one of the most widely used tools for this aim [9], [10]. In addition, a better understanding of the complex potential provided by awareness for the containment of epidemics is a hot spot that continues to attract attention in many different directions, as testified by a multiplicity of studies involving homogeneous spread qualitative models [11], [12], [13], [14], [15], networks [16], [17], [18] and multilayer or multiplex networks [19], [20], [21], [22], [23]. In evaluating the impact of awareness on disease spread, network-based models can certainly offer a deeply realistic perspective since they account for the heterogeneous structure of society and for the individuality of the members of a population. Nevertheless, qualitative spread models benefit of a simpler mathematical treatment and can offer a profound mechanistic understanding. Moreover, they can be considered as a kind of ‘step zero’ when it comes to the spread analysis over networked systems [24]. This study, that moves exactly in this qualitative perspective, has as a starting point the SEIR-like model developed in [14] (1)S˙=Λ−μS−βI(1+aI)S−γUSE˙=βI(1+aI)S−σE−μEI˙=σE−αI−μI−kIR˙=kI−μRU˙=ρI−ρ0Uthat incorporates (i) the role of asymptomatic/undocumented cases in the infection process by means of an overexposure mechanism (ii) awareness, carried out through campaigns or targeted actions, and seen as a tool to increase social distancing. In model (1), the positive parameters involved have the following meaning: Λ is the recruitment rate; μ is the natural death rate; β is the transmission rate; a is the overexposure coefficient; 1/σ is the incubation period; α is the disease-related death rate; k is the cure rate; γ is the dissemination rate of awareness among susceptibles; ρ0 is the depletion rate of the awareness programs whereas ρ is their implementation rate. It is assumed that the many asymptomatic/undocumented individuals can cause an although unconscious overexposure of susceptibles to infection and an incidence rate β(I)=βI(1+aI) is considered. This choice reflects an increased rate of infection due to double exposures over a short time period: single contacts make infection develop at the rate βIS whereas new infections are caused by double exposures at a rate βaI2S [25]. Such incidence rate was linked to the occurrence of hysteretic phenomena through a backward bifurcation scenario [25], [26], a phenomenological framework that involves subcritical persistence of the disease and that needs to be carefully monitored and managed [27], [28], [29], [30]. Media awareness campaigns were instead considered by the means of an awareness variable U(t) that was supposed to have the effect of isolating a fraction of susceptibles and whose governing equation was given by the balance between an implementation and a depletion process. In [14], the interplay between overexposure and awareness was recognized to be a point that should not be underestimated both in the current and future management of Covid19 emergency since, if overexposure can lead system dynamics towards a backward phenomenology, a responsible role of information - aimed at a correct management of awareness - can allow to avoid such a scenario. Dangerous dynamical transitions could be hence avoided through a suitable management of people awareness and factors as information dissemination, implementation and depletion must be adequately monitored and balanced.

While in [14] awareness is considered as a system variable ruled by an assigned evolution equation, in this paper we want to regard the role of awareness from a different perspective. To this aim, we consider awareness as a time-dependent variable whose dynamics is not assigned a priori and, exploiting its potential to produce social-distancing and self-isolation among susceptibles, we use it as an indirect control on the class of infective individuals. In the following, we hence focus on the model(2)S˙=Λ−μS−βI(1+aI)S−U(t)SE˙=βI(1+aI)S−σE−μEI˙=σE−αI−μI−kIR˙=kI−μRand use the Z-control approach to detect what trend over time must awareness U=U(t) display in order to eradicate the disease. The Z-type control approach, an error-based method proposed to solve dynamic problems [31], [32], [33], has recently extended its range of applications moving from engineering to life sciences problems. In population dynamics, it has been applied to the classical and generalized Lotka-Volterra model [34], [35] in order to promote ecological coexistence; in epidemics, to control disease in simple susceptible-infected models [36], [37] and as a means to control the occurrence of backward scenario [38]; in eco-epidemiology, to prevent system dynamics by chaotic oscillations in a predator-prey model with disease infection in the prey [39], [40].

If applied to the ecological or epidemiological field, the Z-type control can be exerted as (i) direct control for all the species, when exogenous measures are applied to the involved populations for the simultaneous control of their dynamics; (ii) as indirect control of one population, when the control measure is only applied to one species with the ultimate purpose to control the other one. The strength of the approach is its interesting property to stabilize the system dynamics towards a desired population density. This is due to the capability of the Z-control approach to change the dynamics of the uncontrolled system [35] driving it towards a desired controlled equilibrium that becomes the only attractor for the Z-controlled model. In the process it is crucial to carefully calibrate the strength of the control exerted on the system.

The existing literature on the Z-control approach has been mainly focused on these dynamical points, dealing with uncontrolled models that can be essentially reduced to two governing equations. As far as we know, an extension of the method to higher-dimensional systems has not yet been provided. Moreover, little attention has been given to the qualitative features of the Z-controller U(t) and to its possible practical applications. With this study, that considers awareness as an indirect Z-control variable for a SEIR-like system, we aim to move a step in both these directions.
On this line, the key contributions of this study, can be summarized as follows:
(i) taking a cue from the structure of the SEIR model, we rigorously extend the Z-control procedure to face the further complication of dealing with a number of governing equations greater than two;

(ii) taking into account the interpretation of the Z-controller U(t) in terms of awareness, we focus on its qualitative features and compare it to some representative trends of interest on the topic ‘Coronavirus’, obtained through a Google Trends analysis. In Google Trends, the RSV trend for a certain search query can in fact be indirectly related to the level of people awareness on that specific topic.

(iii) exploiting the theoretical framework of the Z-control, combined with the comparison of the RSV in the cases of Italy and New Zealand, we take the chance to reflect on the use of Google Trends not only as a tool for monitoring the level of awareness but also as a possible indicator of good management of the epidemic. By good management, we mean here the global set of actions ranging from information campaigns to restrictive actions aimed at containing the virus.

The paper is hence structured as follows. In Section 2 we introduce the uncontrolled SEIR model and briefly recall its properties in terms of equilibria and bifurcations. In Section 3, awareness is introduced in the model as an indirect control on the class of infective population and the Z-controlled model is derived. In Section 4, the Z-controlled model is analyzed in terms of its equilibria, stability properties and positiveness of solutions. In Section 5 investigations in the time dependent regimes are provided to show the effects of the Z-control approach on some representative dynamics of the original model. In Section 6, we combine our findings from the Z-control method with the RSV trends related to the search query ‘Coronavirus’ for Italy and New Zealand to get further insight on the role of awareness in the management of the pandemic. In Section 7, some concluding remarks end the paper.

sec.title: The uncontrolled SEIR model
sec.p: The SEIR-like model (1), without the contribution of awareness, becomes:(3)S˙=Λ−μS−βI(1+aI)SE˙=βI(1+aI)S−σE−μEI˙=σE−αI−μI−kIR˙=kI−μRwhere the total population N(t) is divided into the susceptible (S), exposed (E), infective (I), recovered (R) individuals and is assumed to be varying and homogeneously mixed so that all people are equally likely to be infected by the infectious individuals if they come into contact.

In the following, we will refer to model (3) as the uncontrolled model. To better highlight the impact of the Z-control on this model, we briefly recall its properties in terms of equilibria and bifurcations. As already highlighted in [14] for model (1), also in system (3) the overexposure mechanism gives the ability to exhibit a multiplicity of endemic equilibria subthreshold and a backward phenomenology.

It is easy to show that solutions of the uncontrolled system (3) with non negative initial data, are positive and bounded and that the setΩ={(S,E,I,R)∈R+4:0≤S+E+I+R≤Λμ}is positively invariant and globally attractive for model (3). We refer to Appendix A for the detailed proof of these preliminary results. Since the first three equations in system (3) are independent on the last one, in the next we will consider the following SEI model:(4)S˙=Λ−μS−βI(1+aI)SE˙=βI(1+aI)S−σE−μEI˙=σE−αI−μI−kISystem (4) admits the disease-free equilibrium P0=(Se,Ee,Ie)=(Λ/μ,0,0). Denoting with(5)Γ1=(μ+σ)(α+μ+k),we introduce the basic reproduction number(6)R0=βΛσμΓ1and state the following result:Theorem 2.1
The disease-free equilibriumP0is locally asymptotically stable forR0<1and unstable forR0>1. Proof
The Jacobian matrix of model (4), is given byJ(S,E,I)=[−μ−βI(1+aI)0−βS(1+2aI)βI(1+aI)−μ−σβS(1+2aI)0σ−α−k−μ]and, when evaluated at P0, admits as eigenvalues η1=−μ whereas η2,3 are solutions of the following second order algebraic equation: η2+(α+k+2μ+σ)η+Γ1(1−R0)=0.
It follows that P0 is locally asymptotically stable if R0<1 and unstable otherwise. □ Remark 2.1
We can express the bifurcation threshold R0=1 in terms of the parameter β. In fact: R0=1⇔β=βc where(7)βc=μΓ1Λσ.

An endemic equilibrium P*=(S*,E*,I*) can also be found for system (4) where(8)S*=Γ1σβ(1+aI*),E*=α+μ+kσI*and where I* is a real strictly positive solution of the second order algebraic equation:(9)AI2+BI+C=0,with(10)A=aβΓ1;B=β(Γ1−Λaσ);C=μΓ1(1−R0).We preliminary observe that B>0⇔a<a*=Γ1/Λσ and C>0⇔β<βc where βc is defined in (7). When R0>1, then C<0 and Δ=B2−4AC is a positive quantity. Applying the Descartes’s rule of signs, it follows that the algebraic Eq. (9) admits a unique real positive root independently of the sign of B. Taking into account of Remark 2.1, the following result holds:Theorem 2.2
Ifβ>βcthen model(4)admits one endemic equilibriumP2*=(S2*,E2*,I2*)withI2*=−B+Δ2AandS2*,E2*given by(8).

When R0<1 then C>0 and, according to the sign of the coefficient B in Eq. (9), two or zero real positive solutions are possible. To detect a possible multiplicity of endemic equilibria under the threshold R0=1, or equivalently β=βc, we hence consider the following quantities:(11)a*=Γ1Λσ,β*=4Γ12aμ(Λaσ+Γ1)2where Γ1 is defined in (5). We observe that the inequality β*<βc is always verified sinceβc−β*=Γ1μ(Γ1−Λaσ)2Λσ(Γ1+Λaσ)2is a positive quantity. We can hence state the following results:Theorem 2.3
Ifβ<βcanda<a*, then Eq.(9)admits no positive solutions so that model(4)admits none endemic equilibrium. Proof
We stress that β<βc implies that the sign of the coefficient C in (9) is always positive. Moreover, condition a<a* implies that the sign of the coefficient B is positive too. Therefore the thesis follows by the Descartes’ rule of signs. □ Theorem 2.4
Leta>a*.
(i) Ifβ*<β<βc, then model(4)admits two endemic equilibriaP2*andP1*=(S1*,E1*,I1*)withI1*=−B−Δ2A,andS1*,E1*given by(8).
(ii) Ifβ<β*then model(4)admits none endemic equilibrium. Proof
We first observe that being β<βc and a>a*, we have that the sign of the coefficient C in (9) is always positive and the sign of the coefficient B is negative. Therefore equation (9) admits two positive real solutions if and only if Δ=B2−4AC>0 and admits no real solution otherwise. Observing that Δ>0⇔β>β* the thesis easily follows. □

The above results suggest the occurrence of a backward bifurcation scenario for the uncontrolled model, with a saddle-node bifurcation at β=β* and a transcritical bifurcation at β=βc. More precisely, as stated in the following theorem, the overexposure parameter a can make the difference between the forward and the backward scenario:Theorem 2.5
(i) Ifa<a*, then system(4)exhibits a forward bifurcation atβ=βc. (ii) Ifa>a*then system(4)exhibits a backward bifurcation atβ=βc. Proof
The occurrence of backward or forward scenario is investigated by the method proposed in [41]. The coefficients in the equilibrium Eq. (9) can be regarded as functions of the parameter β so that, at β=βc, C(βc)=0 and Eq. (9) becomesA(βc)I2+B(βc)I=0,with roots I=0 and I=−B(βc)A(βc). The root I=0 refers to the disease-free equilibrium whereas I=−B(βc)A(βc) refers to a positive endemic equilibrium only if B(βc) and A(βc) have opposite signs. Therefore, being A(βc)>0, then B(βc)<0 must hold. Implicit differentiation of Eq. (9) with respect to β gives(2AI+B)dIdβ+dAdβI2+dBdβI+dCdβ=0,that evaluated at I=0 and for β=βc, returns:(12)B(βc)dIdβ(βc)=−dCdβ>0,since, by (10), dCdβ<0. It follows that the slope of the bifurcation curve at I=0 must have the same sign of B(βc). Therefore: (i) if B(βc)<0 then a backward bifurcation occurs at β=βc; (ii) if B(βc)>0, then system displays a forward bifurcation at β=βc. By (10), it follows that B(βc)=Γ1μ(Γ1−Λaσ)Λσ, so that B(βc)<0 if and only if a>a*. □

To show that both the forward and backward scenarios can be compatible with the Covid19 spread in Italy, we choose the parameter values in way to be in line with the Covid19 spread in Lombardy, one of the northern regions of Italy most affected by the virus. The demographic parameters Λ and μ are chosen such that Λ/μ=10036258 (as the total population of Lombardy in 2019) [42]. The average lifespan is taken to be 1/μ=83 years (i.e. μ=0.000033 per day) [42] so that Λ=331 people per day. The incubation period (time from exposure to the development of symptoms) can vary greatly among patients and it is estimated to be between 2 and 14 days [43] with an average of 5.2 days [44]. Therefore σ=1/(5.2) days−1. The WHO reports time from onset of symptoms to death of about 2 weeks [45] and the disease-induced death rate for infectious individuals is assumed to be α=1/8 days−1 [46]. Moreover, the average hospital length of stay of discharged patients is 13 days [47], so that we assume the cure rate to be k=1/13 days−1. The parameters a and β are instead assumed to be varying.

With the above parameter values, the transcritical bifurcation threshold βc is such that βc=2.0143·10−8 whereas a*=0.0006. The impact of overexposure for the emergence of a forward or a backward scenario is shown in Fig. 1 . For a=0.0001<a*, the classic forward scenario is obtained where no endemic equilibria can be detected subthreshold, Fig. 1 (Left). Differently for a=0.006>a*, a backward scenario is obtained where a multiplicity of endemic equilibria can be detected subthreshold, Fig. 1 (Right). We want now to show how such phenomenologies can be Z-controlled with using awareness as an indirect control variable. To this aim, we have first to build the Z-controlled model.Fig. 1
(Left) Low overexposure: a=0.0001<a*. Bifurcation diagram in the plane (β,I*) showing a transcritical bifurcation occurring at β=βc=2.0143·10−8. For β>βc a unique endemic equilibrium exists whereas no endemic equilibrium can be found subthreshold. The numerical value for the other parameters are as fixed in the main text. (Right) High overexposure: a=0.006>a*. Bifurcation diagram in the plane (β,I*) showing the coalescence of the two endemic equilibria E1 and E2 at the saddle-node bifurcation threshold β=β*=6.751686784·10−9. A transcritical bifurcation occurs at β=βc=2.0143·10−8.Fig. 1

sec.title: The Z-controlled model: system derivation
sec.p: Starting by model (4), we want to apply the Z-control approach to perform an indirect control on the infectives by acting on the susceptible individuals. Therefore, we focus on the model:(13)S˙=Λ−μS−βI(1+aI)S−U(t)SE˙=βI(1+aI)S−σE−μEI˙=σE−αI−μI−kIwhere the awareness control variable U=U(t) may assume both positive and negative values. Starting from the initial conditions (S0,E0,I0) at t=0, we want to drive the infective population I(t) toward a desired constant level Id<I0, namely I(t)→Id, with Id≥0.

To derive the related Z-controlled model, we need to develop for model (13) an analysis similar to that we carried out in [38]. In this case, however, the Z-control procedure needs to be adequately extended in order to face the further complication of dealing with a number of governing equations greater than two. Therefore, we preliminary provide a generalization of the Z-control procedure. To the best of our knowledge, this is an original result within the theoretical literature on the subject.

sec.title: A generalization of the Z-type control procedure
sec.p:
We start by recalling that the Z-type approach can be used to control systems described by a set of N autonomous ordinary differential equations(14)y˙=f(y,u)for the variable y=[y1,y2,⋯,yN]T. The idea behind such a error-based dynamic method is to design an analytical expression for the system input u=u(t)∈RM, M≤N, so that the actual system output y(t) is forced to achieve a desired output yd [33], [34], [48]. Given a vector valued norm ∥·∥, if the error between the actual output of the system and its desired state yd(t) approaches zero, i.e.∥v1(t)∥=∥y(t)−yd(t)∥→0,then the Z-control turns out to be successful. To achieve this goal we define the vector v1(t) as first error function and force this quantity to converge to zero exponentially. This is obtained by requiring that the following differential equation(15)v˙1(t)=−λv1(t)is verified. Equation (15) is referred as design formula and the strictly positive parameter λ, called design parameter, gives a measure of the convergence rate. If the design formula yields equations that explicitly include the system input variables u(t), then we obtain an explicit expression for u(t). Differently, if Eq. (15) does not explicitly include the system input u(t), another error function needs to be defined and the design formula is adopted again. To go into more details, we recursively define the nth error function, namely the vectorvn:=v˙n−1+λvn−1,n≥2,and state the following result:Proposition 3.1
Requiring that, forn≥2, thenth error function verifies the design formula(16)v˙n(t)=−λvn(t),is equivalent to require that the first error functionv1verifies the following equation(17)∑k=0n(nk)λkdn−kv1dtn−k=0where we convey thatd0v1dt0:=v1. Proof
The proposition is proved by induction. □ Lemma 3.1
Forμ˜>0,β˜>0andt≥0, there existμ>0andβ>0, such thatμ˜exp(−β˜t)ti≤μexp(−βt)ti−1fori=1,⋯,n−1. Theorem 3.1
For a continuously differentiable and bounded desired stateyd(t)that starts from a positive initial stateyd(0), the first error functionv1(t)=y(t)−yd(t)verifying Eq.(17), converges to zero exponentially. Proof
Solving the nth-order differential Eq. (17), for all t>0, we obtainv1=exp(−λt)v1(0)+texp(−λt)v2(0)+⋯+tn−1exp(−λt)vn(0).From Lemma 3.1 there exists v˜>0 and λ˜>0, such that v1(i)≤v˜(i)exp(−λ˜t) for i=1,⋯,N. Therefore, the first error function v1 exponentially converges to zero with rate λ˜. □

The design procedure for the control law of the Z-type dynamic method is based on the choice that M≤N and n≥1 in such a way that Eq. (17) includes the system input u(t). For example, if we consider the application of the Z-control method to the SIR model in [38], we observe that the value of M was set to 1 as the control was done implicitly only on the susceptible population, whereas n in (17) was set to 2 in order to obtain the equation for v1,v¨1+2λv˙1+λ2v1=0,where v1:=I(t)−Id(t). This allowed to get the analytical expression for the control U(t) in order to drive the infective population towards a desired constant level Id.
Now we explicitly show that, with imposing the third error function to decade exponentially as in (16), we can get the analytical expression for the control U(t) in model (13).

sec.title: Building the Z-controlled SEIR model
sec.p: We first regard model (13) as(18)S˙=−F(I)S+U˜E˙=F(I)S−σ˜EI˙=σE−α˜IwhereF(I)=βI(1+aI),α˜=α+μ+k,σ˜=σ+μ,and(19)U˜=Λ−μS−U(t)S.We hence make use of the indirect Z-type control procedure by following the key steps introduced in the previous subsection. Let Id≥0 the desired state for the infective population. We require that the first error function v1:=I(t)−Id verifies (17) with n=3, namely(20)v1...+3λv¨1+3λ2v˙1+λ3v1=0,and rewrite the above formula in terms of susceptible-infective populations. First observe that,(21)v˙1=I˙,v¨1=σE˙−α˜I˙ (22)v1...=σ∂F∂ISI˙−σ(σ˜+α˜)E˙−σF(I)2S+σF(I)U˜+α˜2I˙Then, with replacing in (20) the expressions (21) and (22), we obtain(23)σF(I)U˜=(η−σ∂F∂IS)I˙+ξE˙+σF(I)2S−λ3(I−Id)where η=3λα˜−3λ2−α˜2, ξ=σ(σ˜+α˜−3λ).

Therefore, for all t such that F(I(t))≠0, we can get the expression of U˜ in (23) so that the modified system (18) can be regarded as(24)S˙=f(S,E,I)E˙=g(S,E,I)I˙=h(S,E,I),where(25)f(S,E,I):=[η−σβ(1+2aI)S]h(S,E,I)+ξg(S,E,I)−λ3(I−Id)σF(I)g(S,E,I):=βI(1+aI)S−σ˜Eh(S,E,I):=σE−α˜IIn the next, we refer to system (24)-(25) as to the Z-controlled model.

sec.title: The Z-controlled model: analytical results
sec.p:
In this section, we investigate the Z-controlled model (24)-(25) in terms of positiveness of solutions, equilibria and stability properties. As far as the former is concerned, we start by observing that, solving (20), we obtain the exact solution for the dynamics of infectives:(26)I(t)=Id+e−λtv1(0)+te−λtv2(0)+t2e−λtv3(0)2,where v1(0)=I0−Id, v2(0)=I˙(0)+λ(I0−Id), andv3(0)=v¨1(0)+2λv˙1(0)+λ2v1(0)=I¨(0)+2λI˙(0)+λ2(I0−Id).Let us consider eλtI(t) with I(t) given in (26) eλtI(t)=eλtId+v3(0)2t2+v2(0)t+v1(0)=c32t2+c2t+c1−(λ22t2+λt+1−eλt)Idwhere(27)c1=I0,c2=I˙(0)+λI0,c3=λ2I0+2λI˙(0)+I¨(0).Positiveness of I(t) is guaranteed if and only if(28)(λ22t2+λt+1−eλt)Id≤c32t2+c2t+c1.Since the function g(t):=λ22t2+λt+1−eλt≤0 for all t≥0 and Id≥0, the following result holds:Theorem 4.1
SetΔ1:=I˙(0)2−I0I¨(0). IfId>0andΔ1<0, thenI(t)in(26)assumes positive values for allt≥0. Proof
From Δ1<0 it follows that the discriminant of c3=c3(λ) assumes negative values. Together with the assumption I0>0, this ensures the positivity of c3 for all λ>0. Moreover,(29)2c3c1−c22=λ2I02+2λI˙(0)I0+2I¨(0)I0−I˙(0)2=I0c3−Δ1>0.If c3>0 and c22−2c3c1<0 then c1>0 and the polynomial c32t2+c2t+c1 assumes positive values for all t≥0. From inequality (28), the result follows.
Now, let us consider eλtI˙(t) with I(t) given in (26) (30)eλtI˙(t)=λ3t22Id−λc32t2+(c3−λc2)t+(c2−λc1).From the dynamics of I(t) we can evaluate:(31)eλtσE(t)=eλt(I˙(t)+α˜I(t))=λ3t22Id−(λ2t22+λt+1−eλt)α˜Id+[c2+(α˜−λ)c1]+(α˜−λ)c32t2+[c3+(α˜−λ)c2]t.Then E(t) is positive when(α˜−λ)c32t2+[c3+(α˜−λ)c2]t+[c2+(α˜−λ)c1]+λ3Id2≥(λ2t22+λt+1−eλt)α˜Id. □

As the right-hand term in the above expression is negative, we can prove the following theorem:Theorem 4.2
IfId>0,Δ1<0andmax(−I˙(0)I0,0)<λ<α˜, thenE(t)in(31)assumes positive values for allt≥0. Proof
From Δ1<0 it follows c3>0 and c1>0. The bounds on λ imply c2>0 and (α˜−λ)>0. Hence the quantity(α˜−λ)c32t2+[c3+(α˜−λ)c2]t+[c2+(α˜−λ)c1]assumes positive values for all t≥0. □

To establish the positivity of S(t), we observe thateλtσS=eλtσE˙+σ˜eλtσEβI(1+aI)and evaluate eλtI¨(t) with eλtI˙(t) given in (30):eλtI¨(t)=λλc32t2−λ(2c3−λc2)t−λ(2c2−λc1)+c3−(λ4t22−λ3t)Id.Then, from (26) and (30), it results thateλtσE˙=eλtI¨+eλtα˜I˙=−λ(α˜−λ)c32t2+[−λc3+(α˜−λ)(c3−λc2)]t−λc2+(α˜−λ)(c2−λc1)+c3+λ3Idt+(α˜−λ)λ3t22Id.From (31) we have that(32)σ˜eλtσE=σ˜eλtI˙+σ˜α˜I=σ˜(α˜−λ)c32t2+[σ˜c3+(α˜−λ)σ˜c2]t+σ˜c2+(α˜−λ)σ˜c1+σ˜λ3t22Id−(λ2t22+λt+1−eλt)σ˜α˜Id.Under the hypothesis (α˜−λ)>0 the quantity eλtσE˙+σ˜eλtσE is positive if(33)(σ˜−λ)(α˜−λ)c32t2+{(σ˜−λ)c3+(α˜−λ)[c3+(σ˜−λ)c2]}t+(σ˜−λ)c2+(α˜−λ)[c2+(σ˜−λ)c1]>0.We can hence prove the following theorem:Theorem 4.3
IfId>0,Δ1<0andmax(−I˙(0)I0,0)<λ<min(α˜,σ˜), thenS(t)assumes positive values for allt≥0. Proof
The hypothesis and the lower bound on λ guarantee that ci>0 for i=1,2,3. Moreover, the upper bound on λ provides the positiveness of both coefficients α˜−λ and σ˜−λ of the polynomial in (33), this assuring the positiveness of S(t) for all t≥0. □

In order to obtain the positiveness of solutions for model (24)-(25), we first evaluateI˙(0)=σE0−α˜I0,I¨(0)=σF(I0)S0−σ(σ˜+α˜)E0+α˜2I0, (34)Δ1=I˙(0)2−I0I¨(0)=σ(σE02+I0(σ˜−α˜)E0−I0F(I0)S0),and then state the following theorem, expressed in terms of the original parameters:Theorem 4.4
SetΔ2=(α+k−σ)2+4βσ(1+aI0)S0. SupposeId,I0,S0>0andα+k−σ>0. LetE0andλverifyα+k−σσ<E0I0<α+k−σ+Δ22σ,α+k+μ−σE0I0<λ<σ+μ,thenI(t),E(t)andS(t)in(24)-(25)assume positive values for allt≥0. Proof
It is easy to verify that, under the assumption I0,S0>0, the discriminant of the second order polynomial Δ1 defined in (34) is positive. Hence Δ1 assumes negative values forα˜−σ˜−Δ22σ<E0I0<α˜−σ˜+Δ22σand the result follows from Theorem 4.1, Theorem 4.2. 4.3. □

In the sequel, we setE0(min)(I0):=I0α+k−σσ,E0(max)(I0):=I0α+k−σ+Δ22σ,and, similarlyλ(min):=α+k+μ−σE0I0,λ(max):=σ+μ.The expression of the unique equilibrium of the Z-controlled model (24)-(25) is given by(35)P*=(Γ1σβ(1+aId),α˜σId,Id)that can be easly deduced from the formula of the endemic equilibrium (8) with I*=Id. Then, the variational matrix J of the Z-controlled model (24)-(25), evaluated at P* is given byJ(P*)=[σ˜+α˜−3λ∂f(Id)∂E∂f(Id)∂IβId(1+aId)−σ˜Γ1(1+2aId)σ(1+aId)0σ−α˜];where∂f(Id)∂E=3λ(α˜+σ˜−λ)−(σ˜2+α˜2+Γ1)βId(1+aId)−Γ1(1+2aId)βId(1+aId)2,∂f(Id)∂I=(α˜−λ)3σβId(1+aId)+Γ1(2α˜+σ˜−3λ)(1+2aId)σβId(1+aId)2.As far as the stability of P* is concerned, the following result holds:Theorem 4.5
The equilibrium(35)of the Z-controlled model(24)-(25)is locally asymptotically stable. Proof
Let us evaluate trace(J(P*))=−3λ<0 and det(J(P*))=−λ3<0 so that the ratio det(J(P*))trace(J(P*))=λ23. Moreover, givenA1(P*)=[−σ˜Γ1(1+2aId)σ(1+aId)σ−α˜],A2(P*)=[σ˜+α˜−3λ∂f(Id)∂I0−α˜], A3(P*)=[σ˜+α˜−3λ∂f(Id)∂EβId(1+aId)−σ˜]it results that∑13det(Ai(P*))=3λ2<λ23=det(J(P*))trace(J(P*)),this concluding the proof. □

sec.title: Investigations in the time dependent regimes
sec.p: In this section, we show that the Z-control approach can be used to control some representative dynamics within both the backward and the forward scenarios. For the numerical simulations, as explained in Appendix B, a positive, non-standard, first order accurate numerical integrator was used. In the time-dependent investigations, we consider β and a as bifurcation parameters whereas the others are fixed as in Section 2. We also recall that, for this choice of the parameters, in the uncontrolled model the transcritical bifurcation threshold βc is such that βc=2.0143·10−8 whereas the overexposure threshold a*=0.0006. According to our theoretical results, low levels of overexposure (a<a*) make the uncontrolled model exhibit a classic forward scenario where no endemic equilibria can be detected subthreshold. Differently, when overexposure is above a certain threshold (a>a*), the uncontrolled model displays a backward scenario, where a multiplicity of endemic equilibria can be detected subthreshold. In the following, we specifically focus on the case where the level of overexposure is high.

sec.title: High level of overexposure
sec.p: In this case, we fix a=10>a* and select three values of the parameter β that correspond to some representative dynamical behaviors above and below the transcritical threshold β*.
Case I. The uncontrolled model exhibits a stable endemic equilibrium super-threshold

We fix the parameter β such that β=2.5·10−8>β*. For this choice of the parameters, we have R0=1.2411 and model (4) admits two feasible equilibria: the disease-free equilibrium P0 that is a saddle point and the endemic equilibrium P2* that is a stable focus. Initial conditions I0=I2*+ϵ and S0=S2*+ϵ, E0=E2*+ϵ with ϵ=10−7, in the neighboring of P2, drive the trajectories of the uncontrolled model (4) towards a situation of stationary endemic disease. The phase portrait related to this situation is represented in Fig. 2 , first column, first row. Now, we consider the Z-controlled model (24)-(25) and, as before, we start from I0=I2*+ϵ and S0=S2*+ϵ with ϵ=10−7. Since α+k−σ=9.6154·10−3>0, the initial value E0=901 is chosen close to the mean value between E0(min)(I0)≈81.9304 and E0(max)(I0)≈1720.82. Moreover, we set λ=0.144 at the mean value between λmin≈9.62143·10−2 and λmax≈1.923·10−1. In so doing, the conditions of Theorem 4.4 are all verified and the positiveness of the controlled susceptible population is theoretically guaranteed. The Z-control forces system dynamics towards the stable equilibrium P*=(8078822.1386,1.0501·10−5,10−5) with Id=10−5 and its effects can be observed by looking at the phase-space of the Z-controlled model in Fig. 2, first column, second row.Fig. 2
High level of overexposure, a=10>a*. Each row in the figure shows, for three different values of the parameter β: the phase-space trajectories for the uncontrolled model (4), the phase-space trajectories for the Z-controlled model (24) when Id=10−5, λ=0.144 and the time dependent behavior of the control variable U(t) exerted on the susceptible population when Id=10−5. In the phase-plane, the initial point (S0,E0,I0) is plotted as a pink diamond, the uncontrolled equilibrium is plotted as a red star and the Z-controlled equilibrium is plotted as a blu circle. First row: β=2.5·10−8>β*. Second row: β=5·10−9<β*. Third row β=4.5·10−9<β*. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)Fig. 2
Case II.

The uncontrolled model exhibits a stable endemic equilibrium sub-threshold We now progressively decrease the value of the parameter β and fix it such that β=5·10−9<β*. For this choice of the parameters, we have R0=0.24922 and model (4) admits three feasible equilibria: the disease-free equilibrium P0 that is a stable node and the two endemic equilibria: P2* that is a stable focus and P1* that is a saddle point. The model hence exhibits a bistability situation sub-threshold. Initial conditions in the neighboring of P2* drive the trajectories of the uncontrolled model (4) towards a situation of stationary endemic disease through a certain number of damped oscillations. The phase portrait related to this situation is represented in Fig. 2, first column, second row. Changing β affects the value of I2* and consequently the values of I0. However, this has a little effect on E0(min)(I0)≈81.9142 and E0(max)(I0)≈1720.48, so that we can consider the Z-controlled model (24)-(25) and start again from E0=901. Similarly λ=0.144 is set inside the interval λmin=9.61935·10−2 and λmax that is unchanged. All the conditions of Theorem 4.4 are verified and the positiveness of susceptible population is theoretically guaranteed. The Z-control forces system dynamics towards the stable equilibrium P*=(40394110.693,1.0501·10−5,10−5) with Id=10−5 and its effects can be observed by looking at the phase-space of the Z-controlled model in Fig. 2, second column, second row.
Case III. The uncontrolled model exhibits a oscillatory behavior sub-threshold

Still decreasing the value of the parameter β, we fix it such that β=4.5·10−9<β*. For this choice of the parameters, we have R0=0.2234 and model (4) admits three feasible equilibria: the disease-free equilibrium P0 that is a stable node and the two endemic equilibria: P1* that is a saddle point and P2* that is now an unstable focus because a couple of complex-conjugate eigenvalues has crossed the imaginary axis. Initial conditions in the neighboring of P2* drive the trajectories of the uncontrolled model (4) towards a situation of oscillatory endemic disease. In fact a stable periodic orbit can be found in the neighboring of P2* because of a Hopf bifurcation that occurs at β=βh=4.53·10−9<β*. The phase portrait related to this situation is represented in Fig. 2, first column, third row. As before, changing β has a little effect on the values E0(min)(I0)=81.9120 and E0(max)(I0)=1720.43 so that, for the the controlled system (24)-(25), we can set E0=901. Similarly, the value of λ=0.144 still lies inside the interval λmin=9.61906·10−2 and λmax. All the conditions of Theorem 4.4 are verified and the positiveness of controlled susceptible population is theoretically guaranteed. The Z-control forces system dynamics towards the stable equilibrium P*=(44882345.214,1.0501·10−5,10−5) with Id=10−5 and its effects can be observed by looking at the phase-space of the Z-controlled model in Fig. 2, second column, third row.

sec.title: Could we associate to awareness a ‘face’?
sec.p: The temporal evolution of the awareness variable U(t) in the third column of Fig. 2, indicates that, to convert an uncontrolled equilibrium super-threshold into a new Z-controlled equilibrium, a stronger effort is required with respect to the one required to change a stationary or an oscillatory uncontrolled behavior sub-threshold. In this sense, dynamical behaviors emerging below the transcritical threshold appear to be more easily modifiable regimes and, among them, the oscillatory trend is slightly less expensive to control. Fig. 2 also shows that, to eradicate the disease, the required trend of awareness is qualitatively similar in the three cases. In fact a phase of low awareness is observed, that grows rapidly until it reaches a maximum and then decreases up to settle - with some oscillations - on a low positive level of constant awareness.

Fig. 3 summarizes the key features of a successful Z-controller when it is used to reduce the infection by a certain percentage (i.e. relative cases reduction) in different endemic situations. This is given by a contour plot (i) of the maximum value and (ii) of the final value of the awareness variable U(t) required by the Z-method to obtain relative cases reduction for different values of R0.Fig. 3
(a) The color bar represents the maximum value of the control variable U(t) during the whole time interval in order to achieve a specific case reduction for different values of R0. (b) The color bar represents the stabilized value of U(t) after achieving a specific case reduction for different values of R0. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)Fig. 3

Fig. 3(a) shows that - for a fixed value of R0 - if the required percentage of infection reduction increases, then also the maximum value of the removal rate U(t) increases. The higher is the value of R0, the higher is the increasing in the maximum of U(t). A similar behavior for the maximum value of U(t) is observed when the percentage of case reduction is fixed and R0 is varied.

Fig. 3(b) shows instead how the final value of U(t) varies to achieve different targets and in different endemicity situations. For fixed values of R0≤5, the final value of U(t) varies slightly as the percentage of infected to be reduced varies whereas for higher values of R0, the variation in the final value of U(t) is more pronounced. Moreover, for a fixed percentage of case reduction, the final value of the awareness variable U(t) increases with increasing the value of R0.

From a practical point of view, it is quite difficult to quantify ‘awareness’. We think however that Google Trends can be used - at least qualitatively - as a mean to associate to the awareness variable U(t) ‘a face’. Google Trends expresses the absolute number of searches relative to the total number of searches over the defined period of interest, allowing to study trends and patterns of Google search queries. For the specified search query of interest, Google Trends provides an index that ranges from 0 to 100, with 100 being the highest relative search term activity [10]. Monitoring how this index varies over time gives hence a measure of how the extent of public attention on a specific topic varies over time. The RSV trend over time can therefore be associated with the public level of awareness regarding a given topic in a certain time interval.

Interestingly, the U(t)-trend observed in Fig. 2 qualitatively resembles the RSV trend for the search query ‘Coronavirus’ during the first phase of the Coronavirus pandemic in Italy (Fig. 4 , top) and obtained through a Google Trends analysis.Fig. 4 (top) shows that a first sign of interest, detectable in a small peak in the RSV, is found in the week of 26Jan-1Feb (point A in the figure) with an interest level of 13%. This is followed by a decrease until the week of Feb 9-15 (point B in the figure) where the interest level is at 5% and by a rapid growth in the week of Feb 23–29 (point C in the figure) when the interest level reaches 87%, decreases in the week Mar 1–7 up to an interest level of 68% (point D in the figure) and, in the week of Mar 8-14 (point E in the figure), the interest level quickly reaches its highest peak with a relative popularity of 100%. From here, a slow progressive decreasing begins that ends in the week June 14–20 with an interest level of 10% (point F in the figure).Fig. 4
The case of Italy. (Top) Trend of the Relative Search Volume (RSV) for the search query ‘Coronavirus’ from the beginning up to August 2020. (Inset) Time-dependent behavior of the awareness U(t) required to Zcontrol an uncontrolled model with high overexposure and a stable endemic equilibrium super-threshold. (Bottom) Trend over time of the newly confirmed Covid19 cases from the beginning up to August 2020.Fig. 4

The high level of interest, corresponding to an increased awareness, recorded in the period March-April could be thought on the one hand as the product of an extensive information campaign and on the other as an indirect effect of the various restrictive measures (lockdown) imposed by the Government in that period. Such an increased awareness - favoring behaviors such as social distancing or intensive use of masks - contributed to the softening of the pandemic curve, inducing a progressive decrease in infections. This can be observed in Fig. 4(bottom), where we report the trend of the new cases per day up to the beginning of August, when it was essentially stable with fluctuations around the value 200.

What happened next is now history and, in Fig. 5 , we report the RSV trend for the search query ‘Coronavirus’ and that of the newly confirmed Covid19 cases from the beginning up to November 2020.Fig. 5(top) indicates that, since August, the RSV trend remains substantially stable, with an interest level below 20% testifying a prolonged period of low interest in the subject. This despite of the dramatic surge in cases that took place since the end of September. Fig. 5(bottom) in fact indicates that from 23 August to 30 September the number of new cases increased with fluctuations around the value 1000 and, from 30 September onwards, they dramatically grew with marked fluctuations, to the point that 39809 new cases were recorded on November 7th: the highest number since the beginning of the pandemic in Italy. The lower interest in this second phase could be partly explained by the fact that, also due to the prolonged emergency, people have likely learned to live with the idea of Covid by deceptively lowering their defenses and causing a situation of decreased awareness. This latter could also have been favored by the often contradictory information on the topic and by the absence of enough drastic and timely containment measures to the virus.Fig. 5
The case of Italy. (Top) Trend of the Relative Search Volume (RSV) for the search query ‘Coronavirus’ over the last year, i.e. November2019-November2020. The dashed black vertical line is a watershed between what happens before and after August2020. (Bottom) Newly confirmed Covid19 cases from the beginning up to November2020.Fig. 5

Fig. 5 highlights in fact that a marked awareness can be associated with a softening of the contagion curve (green circles on the left of the vertical bar) whereas a prolonged low level of awareness can instead be related to a dramatic and persistent surge in the new cases (red circles on the right of the vertical bar).

This result is not in contrast with the indications provided - in terms of awareness - by the Z-control. In fact, the Z-method suggested that, starting from a situation of endemicity super-threshold, a sufficiently low level of awareness can persist only after the disease has been eradicated (Id≈0), something that, for example, did not happen in Italy. Contextualizing the Italian situation within the theoretical framework of the Z-control and imagining that a first effect of the method was to produce a daily level of new infections just under 200, a reapplication of the method would have been desirable, to progressively drive the disease towards the eradication. In this way, the control variable U(t) would have settled on a low level of awareness after a small number of damped oscillations. This kind of behavior can be observed for example in the RSV trend concerning the search query ‘Coronavirus’ and ‘Covid’ in New Zealand, a country associated with a successful management of the Covid epidemic [49] since the number of new cases per day remained very low until now, Fig. 6 (bottom). Fig. 6(top) shows in fact that the RSV trend concerning the search query ‘Coronavirus’ and, even more markedly, that for the search query ‘Covid’ displays a damped oscillatory pattern. This peculiar shape of the RSV trend could be the indirect effect of the specific set of non-farmaceutical interventions adopted in New Zealand, from the very beginning, with the aim to bring Covid-19 incidence to zero [49], [50]. It is in fact reasonable to think that factors as early decisive reactions from health authorities, performant surveillance systems, targeted testing strategies as well as stringency have fed, when necessary, the level of people awareness, preventing it from settling on a fading value that, as in Italy, soon proved to be inadequate with respect to the dangerousness of the situation.Fig. 6
The case of New Zealand. (Top) Trend of the Relative Search Volume (RSV) for the search query ‘Coronavirus’ and ‘Covid’ over the last year, i.e. November 2019 - November. (Bottom) Newly confirmed Covid19 cases from the beginning up to November 2020.Fig. 6

sec.title: Concluding Remarks
sec.p: Many times, throughout the course of this Covid-19 pandemic, we were told that its course would depend mainly on our behaviors. This study is, in a certain a sense, a further validation of this idea. In this paper, we used the Z-control approach to stress the peculiar role that awareness can play for the management of epidemics that, just like Covid-19, display a high rate of overexposure also because of the large number of asymptomatic people.

We considered a SEIR model including a overexposure mechanism and used the potential of awareness to produce social distancing and self-isolation among susceptibles as an indirect control on the class of infective individuals. We generalized the Z-control procedure to appropriately treat an uncontrolled model with more than two governing equations and analytically investigated the resulting Z-controlled system in terms of equilibria and stability properties. Numerical simulations allowed us to show that the Z-control approach can be used to control some representative dynamics within both the backward and the forward scenarios when the level of overexposure is sufficiently high. Time dependent investigations confirmed in fact that the application of the Z-control method can change the uncontrolled model - potentially capable to exhibit a multiplicity of equilibria and both stationary and oscillatory behaviors - into a Z-controlled model that admits the Z-controlled equilibrium as a unique attractor. In so doing, it effectively neutralizes the occurrence of any backward scenario. The trend of the awareness variable U(t) was shown to display some qualitative features common to all the representative dynamical situations we investigated: it before grows and then decreases until settling, after some oscillations, on a low positive level of constant awareness. We hence investigated the relation between the infection reduction and awareness with respect to the value of R0, and how awareness changes in the different endemicity situations.

From a more practical point of view, we qualitatively related the awareness variable U(t) to RSV Google Trends data on Covid-19 and discussed them in the perspective of the Z-control approach, inferring some qualitative indications in view of the disease control.

Our analysis would seem to suggest that an RSV characterized, over time, by damped oscillations can be considered an indicator of good management and could hence be linked to the containment of the epidemic. Differently, an RSV index that quickly settles on low constant levels and remains in this state despite the disease has not been eradicated at all, would indicate that something in the management is not working well. This situation would therefore be connected to possible critical re-emergences of the epidemic.

Indeed, the analysis developed in the present paper and the obtained results might be refined by pushing the simple interplay model here considered in the more involved framework of the network-based models. Multilayer or multiplex networks may in fact lead to some hidden patterns of influences and could provide different outcomes, hence improving the qualitative suggestions provided through the presented approach. An interesting future development of our research goes exactly in this direction.

With this study, we feel to have added further evidence to the idea that suitably strengthening awareness can be crucial for a good management of the Covid-19 pandemic. These months of pandemic have in fact taught us that Covid19 is a complex system and it must be treated such as, acting on several fronts through a multidisciplinary approach. Among the various weapons at our disposal, awareness is perhaps the most powerful. In a recent interview [51], Ilaria Capua, Director of the University of Florida’s One Health Center of Excellence stated: ‘We are Covid-19, its strength is in our behavior, its ability to spread depends on the many variables that characterize our cities’. This is the reason why hundreds of thousands of tampons for day, alone, cannot stop the virus but our behaviors can strongly help to do it.

sec.title: Credit Author Statements
sec.p: D.L. and F.D. contributed to the conceptualization of research, to the formal analysis of the results and to the writing, review & editing of the manuscript.

sec.title: Declaration of Competing Interest
sec.p: The authors of the manuscript declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Appendix A
sec.p:
Assume that the solution (S(t),E(t),I(t),R(t)) of system (3) with positive initial data (S0,E0,I0,R0) exists and is unique on [0,T), 0<T≤∞. We prove it is non negative and bounded on [0,T).Proposition A.1
Let(S(t),E(t),I(t),R(t))be the solution of model(3)with initial conditions(S0,E0,I0,R0)on[0,T). Then(S(t),E(t),I(t),R(t))is nonnegative on[0,T). Proof
We show that S(t)>0 for all t∈(0,T). Let us suppose S(t)≥0 for t∈(0,σ), with S(σ)>0 and σ<T. If a t1∈(σ,T) exists such that S(t1)<0, then we must find a t0∈(σ,T) such that: S(t0)=0 and S(t)≥0 for t∈(σ,t0). This implies S˙(t0)<0 that is in contradiction with S˙(t0)=Λ>0. Therefore S(t)>0 for all t∈(0,T).
As far as the positivity of E(t) and I(t), we consider the following cases:
(i) E0=0 and I0=0. In this case, by the second and third equation in system (3) it follows that E(t)=I(t)=0 for all t∈(0,T).
(ii) E0>0 and I0=0. By continuity arguments and observing that I˙|t=0=σE0>0, it follows that E(t)>0 and I(t)>0 for all t∈(0,T). Otherwise, some t∈(0,T) will exist such that E(t) or I(t) vanishes. Then we denote with t*=inf{t∈(0,T):E(t)=0∨I(t)=0}. Suppose that E(t*)=0. Then, for 0≤t≤t*, it holds E˙≥−(σ+μ)E so that E(t*)≥E0e−(σ+μ)t*>0 that contradicts our assumption. Hence E(t)>0 for all t∈(0,T).
Suppose that I(t*)=0. Then a τ>0 exists, such that t*−τ>0 and such that 0<I(t)<δ for t∈(t*−τ,t*). By the third equation in system (3) one has I˙≥−(α+μ+k)I so that I(t*)≥I(t*−τ)e−(α+μ+k)τ>0, that contradicts our assumption. Hence I(t)>0 for all t∈(0,T).
The same arguments can be used to prove the other cases (iii) E0=0, I0>0; (iv) E0>0, I0>0.
The positivity of R(t) can be deduced from the forth equation in system (3) observing that R(t)≥e−μt>0 for all t∈(0,T). □

The above results allow us to show boundedness of solutions. Setting ω=S+E+I+R, from system (3) one has: ω˙=Λ−μω−αI. The following inequalities hold: Λ−(μ+α)ω≤ω˙≤Λ−μω, so that lim inf(S+E+I+R)≥Λ(μ+α)>0, lim sup(S+E+I+R)≤Λμ and the orbits of (3) with non negative initial data are bounded.

Lastly, we prove the existence of a positively invariant and attractive set for model (3).Proposition A.2
The setΩ={(S,E,I,R)∈R+4:0≤S+E+I+R≤Λμ}is positively invariant and globally attractive for model(3). Proof
Setting ω=S+E+I+R, from system (3), direct calculations show that: ω˙≤Λ−μω, so that ω(t)≤Λμ−[Λμ−ω(0)]e−μt.
Therefore, if ω(0)≤Λμ, then ω(t)≤Λμ, resulting Ω a positively invariant set for model (3). Moreover, if ω(0)≥Λμ, then limt→∞ω(t)≤Λμ so that Ω is globally attractive for model (3). □

sec.title: Appendix B
sec.p: In our simulations, the positivity of the numerical integrator turned out to be crucial to obtain physically meaningful approximations. In fact, as extensively reported in the literature, the use of positive integrators much improve the results whenever positive quantities (i.e. density, concentration) need to be numerically simulated [52], [53], [54], [55], [56], [57].

For certain ranges of the parameters, model (4) can provide a clear example of the possible failure of classical numerical tools, implemented in robust Matlab routines, when they are used to approximate the temporal dynamics. For example, in Fig. 7 we report the solution of SEI model (4) in the interval [0,106] when a=0.0002, β=3.5·10−8 and the other parameters are fixed as in Section 2. The chosen initial conditions are (S0,E0,I0)=(0.9,0.8,0.7). We used ode45 and ode15s codes with both default and at machine precision tolerances. For this choice of the parameters, it is evident the fail in performance of both the methods with tolerances AbsTol=10−6,RelTol=10−3 (Fig. 7, rows 1,2,3) as the solution tends to an attracting negative equilibrium. Less evident is the failure when the tolerances are set at AbsTol=10−14,RelTol=10−13, even if the two Matlab codes show two different long-run regimes. Matlab ode45 provides an oscillating solution (Fig. 7, column 1, rows 4,5,6) whereas ode15s, after some initial oscillations, seems to converge to a positive equilibrium (Fig. 7, column 2, rows 4,5,6). A deeper investigation shows however that the detected oscillations of E(t) and I(t) are around zero, so that both variables assume negative values (Fig. 8 , column 1, rows 1,2). The solution obtained with ode15s converges instead toward a negative equilibrium (Fig. 8, column 2, rows 1,2).Fig. 7
Approximated solutions of model (4) in the temporal horizon [0,106] provided by Matlab routines ode45 (on the left), ode15s (on the right) with default tolerances (rows 1,2,3) and tolerances set at machine precision (4,5,6). Parameters are fixed as in Section 2 with a=0.0002, β=3.5·10−8. Long-run regimes: the solution tends to an attracting negative equilibrium (rows 1,2,3), to an oscillating solution (column 1, rows 4,5,6) or, after some initial oscillations, converges to an equilibrium (column 2, rows 4,5,6).Fig. 7Fig. 8
Approximations of E(t) (first row) and I(t) (second row) of model (4) at the selected times of temporal horizon [0,106] where they assume negative values. Solutions provided by Matlab routines ode45 (on the left), ode15s (on the right) with default tolerances (rows 1,2,3) and tolerances at machine precision (4,5,6). Parameters are fixed as in Section 2 with a=0.0002, β=3.5·10−8. The negative values provided by Matlab routine ode45 (column 1, rows 1,2) oscillate very close to zero. The negative values provided by Matlab routine ode15s (column 2, rows 1,2) depart from zero and converge toward a equilibrium.Fig. 8

The above experiments hence suggest that the use of a positive numerical integrator can be mandatory in order to adequately detect dynamical regimes through numerical investigation. Among the most popular integrators, Implicit Euler rule is the only which grants for positivity. Successive approximations computed by modified Newton method used to solve the nonlinear system, may induce the lost of positivity [58]. In [56], novel geometric numerical integration schemes accurate up to the second order, that are both explicit and positive have been introduced. They are generalized non-standard first and second-order schemes that advance in time according to a non linear functional dependence on the temporal step size that assures the solution to be positive. In this paper we used the first order integrator that advances in time according to the following steps.

Starting from S0,E0,I0≥0,(36)Sn+1=Sn+ΦΔt(q(In))(Λ−μSn−βIn(1+aIn)Sn)En+1=En+ΦΔt(q(In))(βIn(1+aIn)Sn−σEn−μEn)In+1=In+ΦΔt(q(In))(σEn−αIn−μIn−kIn),for n≥0, and ΦΔt(q(I)):=1−e−Δtq(I)q(I) where q(I):=3μ+σ+α+k+βI(1+aI)>0. The sequences Sn≈S(tn), En≈E(tn), In≈I(tn) provide the approximated solutions at the temporal grid tn=nΔt, with Δt>0 representing the temporal stepsize. In [56] it is proved that the functional dependence of Φ on both the temporal stepsize and the variable In, enforces the positivity of the solution of (36) for any value of Δt>0. However, restrictions on the stepsize may arise from the stability requirements. A linear stability analysis may in fact be performed in correspondence of the model equilibria in order to detect restrictions on the temporal stepsize due to stability requirements. This point is out of the scopes of this paper, so here we simply reduced the stepsize until the numerically evaluated eigenvalues of the Jacobian J˜(P) ensure solutions of the positive discrete map (36) to behave, asymptotically, in accordance with the theoretically predicted ones.
